content:
BEGININPUT
BEGINCONTEXT
url: https://www.britannica.com/biography/Christopher-Columbus
ENDCONTEXT
In 1492, Christopher Columbus set sail from Spain with three ships - the Santa Maria, the Pinta, and the Niña - and landed in the Americas. This voyage marked the beginning of extensive European exploration and eventual conquest of the New World. Columbus himself believed until his death that he had reached Asia. 

ENDINPUT
BEGININSTRUCTION
Where did Christopher Columbus land during his 1492 voyage and what were its implications?

ENDINSTRUCTION

BEGININPUT
Christopher Columbus landed in the Bahamas during his 1492 voyage, specifically on an island he named San Salvador. This landing had profound implications, as it initiated sustained contact between Europe and the Americas, leading to widespread exploration, colonization, and the transfer of plants, animals, culture, disease, and technology between the Old and New Worlds—a period known as the Columbian Exchange. This event also set the stage for the eventual establishment of European colonies across the Americas and the beginning of the transatlantic slave trade.
